prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a total of 7.4 hours to obtain 12CO(1-0) line in 0.8 arcsec (extended configuration) resolution at Band 3. We are planning to use 1.875 GHz bandwidth per spectral window in the dual polarization mode, and the bandwidth per polarization will be set to 10 km/s resolution.
The peak of the 12CO(1-0) emissions on each objects (NGC0023, ESO557-G002, NGC7678, NGC0232, ESO320-G030, IC5179) are 435.5, 1080, 2825, 1385, 905 and 1340 mJy/beam, respectively, estimated by our Mopra single dish data with 33 arcsec beam size. The typical FWHM of 12CO(1-0) line width is assumed 150 km/s for our sample. In order to obtain enough resolution to estimate a bulge shape with bulge-disk decomposition, we need about 2 - 300 pc scale resolution which is the same typical size as our Pa-alpha imaging data (0.8 arcsec). We estimated a typical Pa-alpha emitting region size in bulges is less than 10 arcsec, therefore it is enough to detect the main diffused component without ACA, because the maximum recoverable scale without ACA is about 25 arcsec in this frequency range. Besides, A single antenna beam size is 54.5 arcsec, therefore it is enough to cover the almost of whole 12CO(1-0) emitting region (Fig 1. in S&TC). Scaling those to the 0.8 beam size, those peak flux densities are estimated 3.7, 9.2, 24.1, 11.8, 7.7 and 11.4 mJy/beam assuming a beam filling factor of 10% (assuming 10 arcsec of typical size of Pa-alpha emitting region). We need 1.1, 1.7, 4.5, 2.2, 1.4 and 2.1 mJy/beam for NGC0023, ESO557-G002, NGC7678, NGC0232, ESO320-G030 and IC5179, respectively, assuming the signal to noises are >5 for each galaxies. Detecting a typical GMA in galaxies, we will set the velocity resolution as 10 km/s, and according to the sensitivity calculator, this requires 7.4 hours of observation time including overhead for a 6-pointing and additional overhead for extra configurations (# of 12m array configurations are 2).
In addition to get 12CO(1-0) spectrums, we will obtain 100 GHz continuum images, simultaneously. These data will be useful to estimate their dust properties (temperature and emissivity) as map by using SED fitting method. For these fittings, we will use Spitzer and Herschel archive data as shorter wavelength points.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent researches suggest that bulges in galaxies are separated into two types according to their kinematics; "classical-bulges" and "pseudo-bulges", and there are two fundamentally different feeding mechanisms for star formation in the different types of bulges; the star formation in classical-bulges occurs by rapid feeding mechanism when large amounts of gas fall into a galaxy, while those in pseudo-bulges occur with slow feeding system. However there are few observational evidences and the mechanism is still an open question. To regulate these theoretical predictions, it is necessary to make clear and establish a missing link between galaxy evolution and two types of bulges, and it is crucial to understand feeding mechanism to the star formation through the properties of molecular gas, which can connect bulge structure and star formation process. We propose 7.4 hours of ALMA observations to obtain 0.8 (200-300 pc) resolution maps of the 12CO(1-0) line for 6 galaxies, which will provide global molecular gas distributions and kinematics used to compare the differences between two types of bulges. Besides, we will compare the SFE using 12CO(1-0) map and Pa-alpha imaging data.
